lexUnit.name: lumber.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: move in a slow, heavy, awkward way.

sentence.text: In the distance the jungle was being cleared for a road , and Alan could see the yellow machines lumbering about , caterpillar treads churning the earth ; he could even hear the faint scream of giant saws over the noise of the crowd on the train .
Speed was a bit of a non event ( although he did score a goal ! ) and Deane lumbered about a bit , but was strong when he got the ball .
THE kind of man who lumbers about like an injured bear : the quintessential tough guy -- strong , silent and self-con .

His wife studied the overweight pair , still brown from a previous holiday , as they lumbered up the steps to their plane .

Then one day Mark was lumbering up Parliament Hill , and Babur came running up from behind .

Soon after nine o'clock his army lumbered forward .

When you find one of these giants embedded in the honey-coloured limestones of central England or the hard blue rocks of Dorset , you might think that such immense creatures could do little but lumber massively along the sea bed .
